PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: De Olho no Céu de Floripa
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Observatório Astronômico da UFSC. Contém três telescóopios: dois refletores de 30cm e uma luneta H-alfa para observação solar. Média de 2500 visitantes por ano. Atende todas manhãs das 9 às 11h para observação solar. Geralmente escolas visitam neste horário. Todas as quartas à noite em sessão conjunta com o planetário. Todas as terças à noite atende escolas.
O projeto envolve 2 bolsistas de extensão, 2 bolsistas "permanência" e também todos meus alunos de PG (no momento três) e os dois de IC.

Levantamento fotométrico de banda estreita de todo céu.
Coordenador do Science Working Group de astrofísica estelar.

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Desenvolvimento de um sistema de robotização para telescópios de pequeno e médio porte.
Atualmente em uso no telescópio de 40cm no Observatório do Pico dos Dias e no Observatório da UFSC. Será utilizado como "command line language" e "scripting language" pela colaboração JPAS.
Desenvolvimento de instrumentação astronômica. Inclui desenvolvimento de procedimentos inovadores e de hardware. Óptica adaptativa e software para análise de dados.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Desenvolvimento de instrumentação astronômica. Inclui desenvolvimento de procedimentos inovadores e de hardware. Óptica adaptativa e software para análise de dados.

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa e Inovação do Estado de Santa Catarina

ORIENTACAO.TITULO-ORIENTACAO: Bancada Óptica para Óptica Adaptativa em Telescópios Gigantes
Detecção de estrelas e estudo de extinção atmosférica com o uso de uma câmera de todo céu

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Projeto de pesquisa geral, estudo de propriedades físicas e evolução de anãs brancas. Astrosismologia em conjunto com a colaboração Whole Earth Telescope (University of Delaware, University of Texas, UFRGS, ...)

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
ABSTRACT:
As part of the Brazilian collaboration on the 4.2m SOAR telescope project we are building an Integral Field Unit spectrograph, SIFUS, whose prototype (Eucalyptus) is being commissioned at the 1.6m telescope of the Pico dos Dias Observatory (Brazil). As the fiber spectra are tightly packed on the CCD (FWHM=3 pixels, spacing between spectra = 3 pixels), special procedures are required for data reduction. We have developed a software package to disentangle the spectra between neighboring fibers. In this work we discuss in some detail the core of the software, which is based on deconvolution of Gaussians to allow for the decontamination of fibers. We present the current version of our package currently in use with Eucalyptus. We also present results obtained from numerical simulations to determine what is the highest packing possible using aperture extraction and Gaussian extraction.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Automating Stellar Spectral Classification

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
ABSTRACT:
The great amount of data obtained today in Astronomical surveys brings a challenge to astronomers: the classification and analysis of these data in a timing manner. Huge scientific databases (millions of spectra) are being generated, demanding work and precious time from specialized people. Particularly, the spectral classification in the M-K system, and accordingly the luminosity classes, requires a reasonable amount of time. An automatic spectral classification system must identify spectral classes for a given spectrum with a low probability of misclassification. This requisite implies the minimization of classification errors (that must not be worse than those a trained person would make), and that possible errors would be limited to a certain number of neighbor classes in the classification scale. It is also desirable that such system would inform a pertinence degree of a spectrum to a number of classes. We introduce a classifier, which uses some machine learning techniques. The main goal of our tool is to identify the M-K system class and subclass and yield a pertinence degree for each classification job.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: A Sorting Algorithm for Astronomical Observations

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
ABSTRACT:
Robotic telescopes carry out observations previously submitted by researchers, and selected by a sorting algorithm. The submission of observations requests may be done remotely, using network applications, and so the presence of researchers at the observatory become unnecessary. The selection of observations to be carried out, and the order they are selected, is the job of the observations scheduler, a crucial component for this kind of observatory. An observations scheduler must select and sort in an approximately optimal manner, that takes into account the appropriate nights and the best moments in those nights. Another decisive requisite is the scientific merit. Multiple observations also need special consideration. The stability of the selected observations list, since unexpected cancellations can occur, equally plays a fundamental role. This work explains an observations scheduler which satisfies the constraints cited above. A functional prototype has issued encouraging results, generating observations lists that cover up to one year, and possibly longer periods.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: The GUTS robotic observatory control system

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We developed a robotic control system for observatories, called GUTS, using a modular approach. Each instrument is controlled by a block of software that is relatively independent from the rest of the system. The blocks interact via network sockets, allowing distributing the instruments in a network of computers. Also, the instrument controlling blocks are themselves modular subsystems. The most important "side effect" about this is that it is easier adapting GUTS for controlling several models of instruments, just by rewriting a small driver program. GUTS has a scheduling system that distributes the programmed observations through the nights, using an optimization algorithm. But given its adaptability, GUTS can also be used in an interactive mode, the instrument control blocks may be used as stand-alone applications.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: An object identification module for a robotic telescope

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Unambiguous object identification is a crucial step in the sucessful operation of robotic telescopes. It is important during target acquisition, in order to ensure that the desired astronomical source is indeed in the acquired frame, and as part of an automated reduction pipeline for CCD photometry/imaging. Here we present a software module for object identification which was implemented for the robotic telescope that are being developed by the astrophysics group of the UFSC. We use the SExtractor software [1] for source detection and a modified version of the FOCAS algorithm [2] for object identification. The code is capable of identifying and linking individual astronomical sources in sequences of CCD frames, as well as of real-time catalogue matching with star catalogues such as the GSC. In the latter case the equatorial coordinates of the center of the frame can be calculated and used to correct the pointing of the telescope. The code is also capable of detecting moving, non-sidereal objects in sequences of frames, and therefore can be used as a tool in the search for asteroids. References: [1] Bertin, E. and S. Arnouts 1996. SExtractor: Software for source extraction. Astronomy and Astrophysics Supplement Series 117, 393-404. [2] Valdes, F. G., L. E. Campusano, J. D. Velasquez, and P. B. Stetson 1995. FOCAS Automatic Catalog Matching Algorithms. Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific 107, 1119.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: WHEN DOES AN A STAR TURN INTO AN AP STAR?

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XXIX Reuniao Anual da Sociedade Astronomica Brasileira
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Boletim da Sociedade Astronomica Brasileira

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Ap stars present high abundance of rare earth elements. These overabundances are understood as the result of radiative diffusion. In the model, the rare earth elements are pushed to the surface by selective radiation pressure as the wavelength where the radiation field is maximum coincides with the wavelength where the rare earths opacities peak. Radiation pressure is helped by the lack of convection in A star envelopes and by the inhibition of turbulence promoted by the magnetic fields. A fundamental question in the investigation of Ap stars is when, in the evolution process, does an A star turn into an Ap star? Previous work by Abt (1979) and Abt & Cardona (1983) have suggested that A stars turn into Ap stars as they age. Later, other workers have questioned this result (see for instance North, 1993). All of the work done after Abt & Cardona was done based on photometric data rather than spectroscopy. Our goal is to solve this controversy studing the ratio of Ap to A stars on open clusters of different ages. Another way to investigate when a A star turns into an Ap star is to study visual multiples. We have obtained classification spectra of 430 late B, A and early F- type stars in 18 open clusters and 120 visual multiples. The spectra were obtained with 4 Å resolution with Cassegrain spectrographs on 1.5m CTIO, 1.52m ESO and 1.6m LNA telescopes. We are further studing if there is a relation between the ratio of Ap to A stars in open clusters and rotational velocities. Preliminary results of Vsin i of B and A stars in the open cluster IC 2602 will be presented.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Looking for a definitive answer for age dependency of peculiar star.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Optical and Infrared Astronomical Instrumentation for Modern Telescopes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Ap stars present high abundance of rare earth elements. These overabundances are understood as the result of radiative diffusion. In the model of radiative diffusion, the rare earth elements are pushed to the surface by selective radiation pressure as the wavelength where the radiation field is maximum coincides with the wavelength where the rare earths opacities peak. Radiation pressure is helped by the lack of convection in A star envelopes and by the inhibition of turbulence promoted by the magnetic fields. A fundamental question in the investigation of Ap stars is when, in the evolution process, does an A star turn into an Ap star? This is an essential problem, because it is connected with the origin of Ap stars, and in the literature there is no agreement if the spectral peculiarity depends on age of stars or not. To solve this problem, we are studying the number ratio of Ap to A stars in open clusters of different ages. So far we have analyzed 18 clusters and classified over 400 stars. However, this number is still not enough to reach a definitive answer. There is not a wide field multi-object spectrograph like Hydra-CTIO at Gemini or SOAR. Blanco and SOAR telescopes will be operated as a complementary pair. We are planing to use the Hydra-CTIO spectrograph at Blanco telescope. With Hydra we will be able to observe all A stars in an open cluster, which have a distance modulus of 14, in a single exposition of 40 minutes (include positioning time). With this instrument we will be able to increase our sample substantially (double our sample in two nights) and have a definitive answer of the dependency of Ap phenomenon with age.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Observations of the Pulsating White Dwarf G 185-32
Testing White Dwarf Crystallization Theory with Asteroseismology of the Massive Pulsating DA Star BPM 37093

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: It was predicted more than 40 years ago that the cores of the coolest white dwarf stars should eventually crystallize. This effect is one of the largest sources of uncertainty in white dwarf cooling models, which are now routinely used to estimate the ages of stellar populations in both the Galactic disk and the Galactic halo. We are attempting to minimize this source of uncertainty by calibrating the models, using observations of pulsating white dwarfs. In a typical mass white dwarf model, crystallization does not begin until the surface temperature reaches 6000-8000 K. In more massive white dwarf models, the effect begins at higher surface temperatures, where pulsations are observed in the ZZ Ceti (DAV) stars. We use the observed pulsation periods of BPM 37093, the most massive DAV white dwarf presently known, to probe the interior and determine the size of the crystallized core empirically. Our initial exploration of the models strongly suggests the presence of a solid core containing about 90% of the stellar mass, which is consistent with our theoretical expectations.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Thirty-Five New Pulsating DA White Dwarf Stars

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
We present 35 new pulsating DA (hydrogen atmosphere) white dwarf stars discovered from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and the Hamburg Quasar Survey (HQS). We have acquired high-speed time series photometry of preselected DA white dwarfs with a prime focus CCD photometer on the 2.1 m telescope at McDonald Observatory over 15 months. We selected these stars on the basis of prior photometric and spectroscopic observations by the SDSS and HQS. For the homogeneous SDSS sample, we achieve a success rate of 80% for finding new variables at a detection threshold of 0.1%-0.3%. With 35 newly discovered DA variable white dwarfs, we almost double the current sample of 39.
@ARTICLE{2004ApJ...607..982M, author = {{Mukadam}, A.~S. and {Mullally}, F. and {Nather}, R.~E. and {Winget}, D.~E. and {von Hippel}, T. and {Kleinman}, S.~J. and {Nitta}, A. and {Krzesi{\' n}ski}, J. and {Kepler}, S.~O. and {Kanaan}, A. and {Koester}, D. and {Sullivan}, D.~J. and {Homeier}, D. and {Thompson}, S.~E. and {Reaves}, D. and {Cotter}, C. and {Slaughter}, D. and {Brinkmann}, J.}, title = "{Thirty-Five New Pulsating DA White Dwarf Stars}", journal = {\apj}, year = 2004, month = jun, volume = 607, pages = {982-998}, adsurl = {http://ads.nao.ac.jp/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2004ApJ...607..982M&db_key=AST}, adsnote = {Provided by the NASA Astrophysics Data System} }

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Whole Earth Telescope observations of the pulsating hot white dwarf PG 1707+427

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
We report on the analysis of multisite time-series photometry of the pulsating pre-white dwarf (GW Vir star) PG 1707+427, obtained by the Whole Earth Telescope collaboration. This is the last of the known GW Vir stars without surrounding nebulae to be resolved by multisite data. Successful resolution of the pulsation spectrum resulted from the combination of high signal-to-noise observations with a large telescope and wide coverage in longitude with smaller telescopes. We find a series of 8 pulsation frequencies (along with two nonlinear combination frequencies), and identify 7 of them as part of a sequence of l=1 modes, with a common period spacing of 23.0 s. This spacing implies that the mass of PG 1707+427 is 0.57 M⊙. Preliminary model fits suggest that the mass determined via asteroseismology is consistent with the mass determined from spectroscopy combined with evolutionary tracks.
@ARTICLE{2004A&A...428..969K, author = {{Kawaler}, S.~D. and {Potter}, E.~M. and {Vu{\v c}kovi{\' c}}, M. and {Dind}, Z.~E. and {O'Toole}, S. and {Clemens}, J.~C. and {O'Brien}, M.~S. and {Grauer}, A.~D. and {Nather}, R.~E. and {Moskalik}, P.~A. and {Claver}, C.~F. and {Fontaine}, G. and {Wesemael}, F. and {Bergeron}, P. and {Vauclair}, G. and {Dolez}, N. and {Chevreton}, M. and {Kleinman}, S.~J. and {Watson}, T.~K. and {Barstow}, M.~A. and {Sansom}, A.~E. and {Winget}, D.~E. and {Kepler}, S.~O. and {Kanaan}, A. and {Bradley}, P.~A. and {Dixson}, J. and {Provencal}, J. and {Bedding}, T.~R.}, title = "{Whole Earth Telescope observations of the pulsating hot white dwarf PG 1707+427}", journal = {\aap}, year = 2004, month = dec, volume = 428, pages = {969-981}, adsurl = {http://ads.nao.ac.jp/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=2004A%26A...428..969K&db_key=AST}, adsnote = {Provided by the NASA Astrophysics Data System} }

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Pushing the ground-based limit: 14-mumag photometric precision with the definitive Whole Earth Telescope asteroseismic data set for the rapidly oscillating Ap star HR1217

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: HR1217 is one of the best-studied rapidly oscillating Ap (roAp) stars, with a frequency spectrum of alternating even- and odd-l modes that are distorted by the presence of a strong, global magnetic field. Several recent theoretical studies have found that within the observable atmospheres of roAp stars the pulsation modes are magneto-acoustic with significant frequency perturbations that are cyclic with increasing frequency. To test these theories a Whole Earth Telescope extended coverage campaign obtained 342 h of Johnson B data at 10-s time resolution for the roAp star HR1217 over 35 d with a 36 per cent duty cycle in 2000 November-December. The precision of the derived amplitudes is 14 mumag, making this one of the highest precision ground-based photometric studies ever undertaken. Substantial support has been found for the new theories of the interaction of pulsation with the strong magnetic field. In particular, the frequency jump expected as the magnetic and acoustic components cycle through 2pi rad in phase has been found. Additionally, comparison of the new 2000 data with an earlier 1986 multisite study shows clear amplitude modulation for some modes between 1986 and 2000. The unique geometry of the roAp stars allows their pulsation modes to be viewed from varying aspect with rotation, yielding mode identification information in the rotational sidelobes that is available for no other type of pulsating star. Those rotational sidelobes in HR1217 confirm that two of the modes are dipolar, or close to dipolar; based on the frequency spacings and Hipparcos parallax, three other modes must be either l= 0 or 2 modes, either distorted by the magnetic field, or a mix of m-modes of given l where the mixture is the result of magnetic and rotational effects. A study of all high-speed photometric Johnson B data from 1981 to 2000 gives a rotation period Prot= 12.4572 d, as found in previous pulsation and photometric studies, but inconsistent with a different rotation pe

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Whole Earth Telescope observations of BPM 37093: A seismological test of crystallization theory in white dwarfs

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: BPM 37093 is the only hydrogen-atmosphere white dwarf currently known which has sufficient mass (~1.1 M⊙) to theoretically crystallize while still inside the ZZ Ceti instability strip (Teff∼12 000 K). As a consequence, this star represents our first opportunity to test crystallization theory directly. If the core is substantially crystallized, then the inner boundary for each pulsation mode will be located at the top of the solid core rather than at the center of the star, affecting mainly the average period spacing. This is distinct from the mode trapping caused by the stratified surface layers, which modifies the pulsation periods more selectively. In this paper we report on Whole Earth Telescope observations of BPM 37093 obtained in 1998 and 1999. Based on a simple analysis of the average period spacing we conclude that a large fraction of the total stellar mass is likely to be crystallized.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Cleito foi bolsista no Grupo de Astrofísica por um período muito curto, cerca de uns 3-4 meses. Neste período conseguiu progredir bastante no trabalho tendo implementado uma interface via web para o sistema de controle do telescópio robótico.
Cleiton era aluno da engenharia elétrica e passou a dedicar-se a um projeto em seu departamento.

Comitê de alocação de tempo do telescópio Gemini

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: O NTAC (national time allocation committee) do Gemini é o comitê brasileiro de distribuição da fração de tempo que cabe aos astrônomos brasileiros no telescópio Gemini. Reúne-se duas vezes por ano.

DADOS-BASICOS-DE-OUTRAS-BANCAS-JULGADORA.TITULO: Comitê de alocação de tempo do telescópio Gemini

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: O comitê de alocação de tempo do Laboratório Nacional de Astrofísica reúne-se duas vezes por ano. Fui suplente neste comitê e participei de uma das reuniões.
